Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: AI- and Data-driven Integrated Framework for Hierarchical Community-level Risk Assessment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The fast evolving and deadly outbreak of coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has created one of the most challenging issues facing global public health. According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), before a vaccine or drug becomes widely available, community mitigation, which is a set of actions that persons and communities can take to help slow the spread of respiratory virus infections, is the most readily available interventions to help slow transmission of the virus in communities. A growing number of areas are reporting community transmission of the virus, which would represent a significant turn for the worse in the battle against the novel coronavirus; this points to an urgent need for expanded surveillance so we can better understand the spread of COVID-19 and better respond with actionable strategies for community mitigation. By advancing capabilities of artificial intelligence (AI) and leveraging the large-scale and real-time data generated from heterogeneous sources, the goal of this project is to design and develop an AI- and data-driven integrated framework to provide real-time hierarchical community-level risk assessment to help combat the COVID-19 pandemic.<br/><br/>The research will have three main parts. First, the research team will construct a novel heterogeneous graph architecture to comprehensively model the large-scale and real-time pandemic related data collected from multiple sources. Second, the team will develop conditional generative adversarial nets for graph enrichment to address the challenge of limited data that might be available for learning. Third, the team will develop algorithms to model potential community transmission routes and design an innovative heterogeneous graph auto-encoder model for hierarchical community-level risk assessment. Through the potential community transmission route modeling, the developed framework will facilitate a predictive understanding of the spread of the virus; by providing the dynamic and real-time COVID-19 risk assessment, the planned work will enable the general public to select appropriate actions for protection while minimizing disruptions to daily life to the extent possible (i.e., mitigate the negative effects of COVID-19 on public health, society, and the economy). The planned research will benefit intelligent information management where multiple data sources are involved and secure and trustworthy cyberspace with applications such as malware detection and mitigation. The project integrates research with education through curriculum development, the participation of underrepresented groups, and student mentoring activities.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The novel coronavirus and its deadly outbreak have posed grand challenges to human society, which points to an urgent need for expanded surveillance so we can better understand the spread of COVID-19 and thus better respond with actionable strategies for community mitigation. By advancing capabilities of artificial intelligence (AI) and leveraging the large-scale and real-time data generated from heterogeneous sources, this project aims to design and develop an AI- and data-driven integrated framework (algorithms, methods and techniques) to provide near real-time hierarchical community-level risk assessment in the US for the combat against the evolving COVID-19 pandemic. With the support of this grant, during the two-year project period, the team has had 29 publications in recognized journals (e.g., IEEE TBD, IEEE TKDE, ACM TKDD, ACM TIST, JBHI) and in proceedings of highly competitive conferences with acceptance rate about or less than 20% (e.g., AAAI'2021-2022, SIAM SDM'2022, WWW'2021, CIKM'2020-2021, ECML-PKDD'2021, KDD'2020, IJCAI'2020), and 1 Ph.D. dissertation. The research outcomes have been widely disseminated to research communities and practitioners through the publications, presentations, seminars, project website and demos, media presses, etc. Specially, with partial support of this project, the PI has received the prestigious ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Award (Full Paper Track), the ACM CIKM 2021 Best Paper Award Runner Up (Applied Paper Track), the CSE Innovation Award (2020-2021) and the CSE Research Award (2019-2020) at Case Western Reserve University (CWRU), and the MetroLab Innovation of the Month (May 2020).

The integrated framework proposed and developed in this project will help estimate the spread of COVID-19 and predict the risks at community levels, and thus provide actionable information to users for community mitigation. The developed system (named α-Satellite) in this project has attracted positive media/public attention from WKYC, NPR, Fox8, WTAM, etc. As of July 15, 2022, the system has had 505,231 users with a lot of good feedback on the ease of use as well as the utility of the relative risk estimation. In addition to the broader societal impacts, the proposed research will be beneficial to research and engineering communities when multi-source multi-modality data are involved. The outcomes of this project (including open-source codes and large-scale datasets) have been made publicly accessible; and broadly distributed through publications, presentations, seminars, demonstrations, etc. The project has integrated research with education through curriculum development, K-12 outreach activities and engaging graduate and undergraduate students in research (e.g., four PhD students, one master student, and four REU students have been recruited). The project has also increased the involvement of underrepresented groups, including minority and women (e.g., three female graduate students, one female REU student, and one underrepresented female high-school student have involved working on AI and data driven research related to this project).

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2022
Modified by: Yanfang Ye

By advancing capabilities of artificial intelligence (AI) and leveraging the large-scale and real-time data generated from heterogeneous sources, this project aims to design and develop an AI- and data-driven integrated framework (algorithms, methods and techniques) to provide near real-time hierarchical community-level risk assessment in the US for the combat against the evolving COVID-19 pandemic. The integrated framework proposed and developed in this project will help estimate the spread of COVID-19 and predict the risks at community levels, and thus provide actionable information to users for community mitigation. The developed system (named α-Satellite) in this project has attracted positive media/public attention from WKYC, NPR, Fox8, WTAM, etc. As of July 15, 2022, the system has had 505,231 users with a lot of good feedback on the ease of use as well as the utility of the relative risk estimation. In addition to the broader societal impacts, the proposed research will be beneficial to research and engineering communities when multi-source multi-modality data are involved. The project has also increased the involvement of underrepresented groups, including minority and women (e.g., three female graduate students, one female REU student, and one underrepresented female high-school student have involved working on AI and data driven research related to this project).
